brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides a rule for validating @Pointcut methods in Aspect Oriented Programming (AOP). The rule checks that these methods have a void return type, do not have a throws clause, and have an empty method body.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'pointcut-method-style' checks all classes and their methods. If a method has the @Pointcut annotation, it asserts that the method's return type is void, it does not have a throws clause, and its body is empty. If these conditions are not met, it generates a message indicating the method and class that violate the rule.
PRE_model_validation: The rule 'pointcut-method-style' is syntactically correct according to the Rule-Specific Language (RSL) syntax. It uses the built-in functions: getClasses, getMethods, hasAnnotation, getReturnType, hasParamType, isEmpty, getBody, getName, and getFQN. No new functions were introduced.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/spring-aop-pointcut-tutorial
Summary: This page provides a tutorial on using @Pointcut in Spring AOP. It explains the concept and usage of pointcuts but does not specifically address the style rules.

Summary: This page from TutorialsPoint explains the concept of Pointcut and Advice in Spring AOP. It provides examples of pointcut expressions but does not discuss the method style rules.
